snippet: The company’s expected tax bill of $6 billion on $36 billion in repatriated cash could be “multiples” less than analysts had estimated.
abstract: General Electric is expected to pay $6 billion in taxes when it repatriates $36 billion of foreign earnings from sale of investment arm GE Capital; GE is largest and most prominent company to repatriate earnings on this scale, yet experts say it is unlikely other companies will follow suit before some kind of tax reform is accomplished, as move is part of company's broader restructuring.

byline.original: By DAVID GELLES and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

lead_paragraph: The company’s expected tax bill of $6 billion on $36 billion in repatriated cash could be “multiples” less than analysts had estimated.

headline.main: G.E.’s Retrieval of Overseas Cash Highlights Tax Debate
headline.print_headline: G.E.’s Retrieval of Overseas Cash Highlights a U.S. Tax Debate
